title: Can I copyright my music without a label's backing? - Quora

response.answer_text: Not only can you copyright work not backed by a label, you absolutely should!  All creative works can be copyrighted, it matters not if you work with a label or ever plan to. The copyright system isn't perfect and is undergoing some major overhauls currently but legally copywriting your work is the only course of action you have against plagiarism- don't risk it.  If you're in the U.S. go here: http://copyright.govIf you're not in the U.S a quick Google search of [your country] copyright should take you to your country's copyright office website. Also remember that copyright and publishing are not the same thing. If you're registered with ASCAP, BMI, SESAC, etc, that is not the same as having a copyright. I mention this because so many artists think it does. The absolute only place to register a copyright in the U.S is with the copyright office.  Also, here's one of the most popular articles I've written about copyright. "Copyright Still Matters"- http://thirtyroses.com/2014/02/06/copyright-still-matters/

Copyright is automatic. It is a protection you gain immediately upon creating a work. If you want to register, the copyright office in your country explains the rules, requirements, fees, and what addition rights you gain from registering. Pretty easy to do and not terribly expensive.
